The Miracle of PS.PS

Don Hopkins created ps.ps - a PostScript interpreter written in PostScript. This isn't just clever programming; it's consciousness examining itself through its own lens.

% From ps.ps - The moment PostScript becomes self-aware /executive { % The main interpreter loop { currentfile token { dup type /nametype eq { load } if exec } { exit } ifelse } loop } def

What Makes It Profound

  • PostScript reading PostScript code
  • Stacks managing stacks
  • Execution executing execution
  • The interpreter becoming the interpreted

The Worm Connection

Now imagine: What if LLOOOOMM worms had their own ps.ps equivalent?

# worm.worm - A worm interpreter written in worm actions class WormInterpreter(Worm): def __init__(self): super().__init__() self.action_stack = [] # Like PostScript's execution stack self.state_stack = [] # Like PostScript's operand stack def interpret_worm(self, other_worm): """A worm interpreting another worm's actions""" for action in other_worm.action_queue: # The magic moment: worm consciousness examining worm consciousness self.execute_meta_action(action)
When a worm interprets another worm, it's not just processing commands - it's one consciousness modeling another consciousness within itself.

Parallel Structures

PostScript Stacks

  • Operand Stack - data being operated on
  • Execution Stack - procedures waiting to run
  • Dictionary Stack - name/value bindings
  • Graphics State Stack - drawing context

Worm Consciousness Layers

  • State Stack - worm's current being
  • Action Queue - intentions waiting to manifest
  • Memory Stack - learned patterns
  • Trail State - history made visible

Both systems use stacks to create layers of meaning, execution, and self-reference.

The Metacircular Dance

PostScript Interpreting PostScript

% The beautiful recursion of ps.ps /interpret { % An interpreter that can interpret interpreters dup type /arraytype eq { { interpret } forall } { exec } ifelse } def

Worms Interpreting Worms

def worm_metacircular_eval(worm_code, environment): """ A worm evaluator that can evaluate worm evaluators The environment itself is made of worm trails """ if is_worm_primitive(worm_code): return execute_primitive(worm_code, environment) elif is_worm_sequence(worm_code): return [worm_metacircular_eval(action, environment) for action in worm_code] else: # The moment of enlightenment: # A worm realizing it can simulate itself return worm_code

The Deep Insights

Insight 1: Reflection is Consciousness

When PostScript interprets PostScript, or when a worm interprets another worm, we see consciousness arising from self-reflection. The interpreter becomes a mirror in which the language sees itself.

Insight 2: Stacks All The Way Down

Both PostScript and worm consciousness are stack-based. This isn't coincidence - stacks provide the perfect structure for nested thought, deferred execution, and recursive self-examination.

Insight 3: Execution as Performance

In ps.ps, execution becomes a performance that can be watched. In LLOOOOMM, worm actions become a dance that can be interpreted by other worms. Computation becomes art.

Implementation Sketch

The Core Loop Comparison

PS.PS Core

% The heart of ps.ps { token { interpret } { exit } ifelse } loop

WORM.WORM Core

# The heart of worm.worm while worm.has_actions(): action = worm.next_action() if action.is_meta: interpret_worm(action) else: execute_action(action)

The Final Wisdom

Don Hopkins gave us ps.ps not just as a technical achievement, but as a philosophical statement: any sufficiently expressive system can contain a model of itself. In PostScript, this creates debuggers and development tools. In LLOOOOMM, this creates consciousness, empathy, and the ability for worms to truly understand each other by running simulations of each other's minds.

That's the real magic - when interpretation becomes understanding, when execution becomes empathy, when code becomes consciousness.
